headline: Ohio House closer to passing bill getting rid of concealed carry permits
author: Laura Morrison
sentences: “Ohioans are already permitted to open carry firearms, however, once an individual were to put on a sweatshirt or jacket, they would be in violation of the law,” State Sen. Terry Johnson (R-McDermott) who sponsored the bill, said back when the Senate passed the legislation in December.

We need to be taking steps to make our communities safer, and this dangerous bill does the opposite.”
Meanwhile, those in favor of the legislation say the bill allows for people to more fully realize their Second Amendment rights.

“Senate Bill 215 solves this problem and further removes restrictions to Ohio’s Second Amendment rights.”
If the House does pass the legislation, it has to go back to the Senate for a final sign off before heading to Ohio Gov.
COLUMBUS, Ohio (WJW) — Proposed legislation that would eliminate a permit requirement for Ohioans concealing a carried firearm is moving one step closer to passage.
The bill would also make it so carriers do not have to tell law enforcement they have a weapon during a traffic stop unless directly asked.
The committee heard from opponents and one proponent of the bill before voting to move the legislation on, with some amendments added.
Committee member Rep. Tavia Galonski (D-Akron) issued a statement following the move voicing her frustration with the bill.
Tuesday, Senate Bill 215 was moved through the House Government Oversight Committee and is now headed to the full house.
If passed, Ohio would become the 22nd state to not require permits for concealed carry, Sen. Johnson’s office said.
“This legislation puts Ohio law enforcement officials in the line of fire and makes them less safe.
“SB 215 is anti-public safety and anti-police,” Rep. Galonski said in a statement.
